source.277b1eec: from deep_autoviml import deep_autoviml as deepauto
source.77246975:
# define train and test files here
train_filename="../input/tps-nov-features/train_features.csv"
target='target'
keras_model_type = "fast1"
project_name = "TPS_Nov21"
source.199f6b7f:
import pandas as pd
train = pd.read_csv(train_filename).drop('kfold', axis=1)
print(train.shape)
train.head(1)
source.afbe7a83:
# deep_autoviml can use multiple model types - we will use the fas1 which is a deep and wide network
model, cat_vocab_dict = deepauto.fit(train, target, keras_model_type=keras_model_type,
		project_name=project_name, keras_options=keras_options,  
		model_options=model_options, save_model_flag=True, use_my_model='',
		model_use_case='', verbose=1)
source.f41d0619:
predictions = deepauto.predict(model, project_name, test_dataset=test,
                                 keras_model_type=keras_model_type, 
                                 cat_vocab_dict=cat_vocab_dict)
len(predictions)
source.d6aa50fc:
import pandas as pd
sample_submission = pd.read_csv("../input/tabular-playground-series-nov-2021/sample_submission.csv")
sample_submission.target = predictions[0][:,1]
sample_submission.to_csv("submission.csv", index=False)
source.c21d6ee8: # It took less than 5 mins to build a deep and wide model with balanced accuracy on validation data set of 71%. Let's see how well the model does on test data.
source.1dc4fff7: # There is a minor problem with train and test: there is one extra feature in Train (kfold) than in Test. Hence we need to remove that feature and train the Deep Learning model.

source.c3be2ad4: # So the model predicts 52 percent of test as 1's similar to what Train data has (50 percent) are 1's. So we may be on the right track though other AutoML programs take 8 hours on this same dataset. So they might produce better results but take far too long compared to Deep_AutoViML. That's the distinguishing feature of Deep_AutoViML: you get a performant model in 5 mins or less even for a very large dataset like Nov TPS.
